Dan Sicko Papers, 1983-2008

did.abstract: The Dan Sicko Papers comprise the written work and research undertaken by Sicko on the topic of Detroit techno music and its significance for the broader techno genre. The collection's four series contain materials pertaining to Sicko's book Techno Rebels: The Renegades of Electronic Funk, articles written over the course of Sicko's career as a freelance music journalist, popular and scholarly articles written by others, industry-specific and general interest periodicals, and sound recordings of interviews with Detroit-based techno artists, producers, and distributors.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were donated to the library in 2012 by Ms. Amy Lobsiger (Donor No. 10870)

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Dan Sicko Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Daniel S. Sicko was a music journalist and scholar of techno music dedicated to legitimizing Detroit techno and establishing its place in music history. He earned a B.S. from the University of Detroit in 1990 and established a career in digital advertising, ultimately serving as a Creative Director of the Detroit office of the advertising firm Organic, Inc. Early in his career Sicko was a freelance writer for Rolling Stone, electronic and underground music periodicals such as Alternative Press and URB, and the digital technology magazine Wired. He also founded Reverb, one of the first periodicals exclusively devoted to digital music. Sicko is perhaps best known for his book Techno Rebels: The Renegades of Electronic Funk (first published in 1999 and reissued in 2010), which is widely considered to be a groundbreaking text with regard to the history of Detroit techno music. Techno Rebels chronicles the genre's origins as an underground movement led by Detroit's African-American high school students. Sicko also gave lectures on the Detroit music scene and was a key figure in the establishment of the 313 Mailing List (a 1990s mailing list critical for enthusiasts of Detroit techno). Throughout his career Sicko engaged in extensive researches on the Detroit music industry and on electronic music in general, for which he conducted dozens of interviews with Detroit-based techno artists and producers. He died of ocular melanoma on August 28th, 2011 at the age of 42.
Source: Kirn, Peter. "Loss of a Techno Rebel: Why Dan Sicko will be Sorely Missed." createdigitalmusic.com, 29 August 2011.

scopecontent.p: The Dan Sicko Papers comprise over two decades of Sicko's writings and research materials pertaining to the history of Detroit techno music and its role in the electronic music industry. The collection is divided into four series: Writings, Research Materials, Periodicals, and Sound Recordings.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Music journalists--Michigan--Detroit.
Musicians--Michigan--Detroit--Interviews.
Techno music--History.
Techno rebels: the renegades of electronic funk.

scopecontent.p: The Writings series is divided into three subseries: Techno Rebels: The Renegades of Electronic Funk (book), Articles and Drafts, and Miscellaneous Papers. The first subseries is composed of materials pertaining to Sicko's book, including drafts, research materials, interview transcripts, and publication materials. The second subseries contains published articles and article drafts written by Sicko about Detroit techno for various electronic music publications (including Anti-Matter Magazine and URB). The last subseries contains miscellaneous correspondence, notes, and resumes.

did.unittitle: Techno Rebels: the Renegades of Electronic Funk (book)
Interviews with Delano Smith, Derrick May, Alan Oldham, others
"Home Bass: Detroit's Electro-Funk Slides into the Limelight" (drafts)
"Methodical Progression: Submerge Represents the new Face of Independent? Underground?"
"Ocean to Ocean: the Rise of the Techno Tourist" (draft)
Articles and reviews published in Anti-Matter Magazine, 1990-1992

odd.p: (given by Sicko, on the topic of Detroit's role in the development of techno)

scopecontent.p: The Research Materials series is divided into three subseries, the first of which (Techno Music and the Music Industry) is comprised of newsletters, periodical articles, and press clippings on the topic of techno music and the electronic music industry in general. This subseries includes articles and research materials pertaining to rave culture, various audio formats, music videos, and international techno. The second subseries (Detroit Techno) contains researches that are specific to Detroit, including scholarly articles and papers, newspaper clippings, and ephemera pertaining to the Detroit techno scene, Detroit music history, and urban renewal. This subseries also contains materials from the Detroit Electronic Music Festival and the Shrinking Cities Project (the latter of which includes Sicko's paper on the Detroit music scene). The third subseries (Musical Artists and Producers) is composed of materials pertaining to individual techno artists, production companies, and record labels (many of them Detroit-based), including biographies, periodical and newspaper clippings, photographs, discographies, press releases, and album reviews. This subseries also includes several interview transcripts and accompanying drafts of articles.

did.unittitle: Techno Music and the Music Industry

"Bubble Metropolis: Expanding Detroit's Identity Through Music" (Sicko) 2003
Detroit Electronic Music Festival (includes itinerary, artist list, press release, ephemera) 2000-2001

"Can't Forget the Motor City" : Creem Magazine, Rock Music, Detroit Identity, Mass Consumerism, and Counterculture" by Michael J. Kramer, 2002

scopecontent.p: The Periodicals series contains several dozen periodicals arranged in alphabetical order by title. These include both mainstream and music industry periodicals, some relatively obscure. The publications in this series are devoted to such topics as techno and electronic music, underground or avant-garde music scenes, the entertainment industry, urban culture, and the city of Detroit. Some include articles contributed by Sicko. The majority are English-language periodicals from the 1990s, among which RES, URB, and The Wire are best represented. Oversized periodicals are listed and housed separately.

The Sound Recordings series contains a total of 36 microcassette tapes which likely consist predominantly of recordings of interviews Sicko conducted with Detroit-based techno artists, producers, and others active in the Detroit electronic music industry. Many of these interviews were likely undertaken for Sicko's book Techno Rebels: The Renegades of Electronic Funk. N.B.: microcassette labeling is occasionally inconsistent or illegible.
